title: Relates to chronic pain disorder as a compensable occupational disease
summary: Adds chronic pain disorder as a justifiable ailment for which one may receive compensatory payments under the workers' compensation law; defines chronic pain disorder as any process which causes pain in patients suffering from diseases known to be chronic and incurable.

memo:
BILL NUMBER:S2239

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
to amend the workers' compensation law, in relation to including chronic
pain disorder as a compensable occupational disease

SUMMARY:
This bill amends chapter 665 of the laws of
1971 by
renumbering paragraph 31 and adding a new paragraph 30. This bill
adds chronic pain disorder as a justifiable ailment for which one may
receive compensatory payments under the workers' compensation laws of
1971, if this disease is a direct result from one's occupation. This
bill grants to those individuals providing evidence of chronic pain
disorder as a result of one's occupation may receive compensatory
payments as delineated in the workers' compensation law, found in
section 3.

JUSTIFICATION:
In recent years, it has been
discovered that many
individuals endure chronic and incurable diseases resulting from
their occupations. The resulting disorder has forced many of these
individuals to relieve themselves from their occupational positions
without receiving any pay. Chronic pain disorder has severe and
irreversible effects.
It is now necessary to incorporate this ailment to the list of those
enumerated under Workers' Compensation Law Section 3.

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:
To be determined.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
This act shall take effect immediately.
